headline: Humanity, Technology, and the Inevitable Alteration of Time Perception
description: A raw first exploration of how digital memory, streaming, and symbolic permanence are changing our relationship with time. A fragmentary reflection on attention, presence, and the recursive imprint of technology.
whyItMatters: This is the seed of a larger exploration: how our tools alter not just attention, but *temporal being*. Even as a rough cut, it surfaces how humans now live as echoes across searchable time.
articleExcerpt: There’s a reason we capture video. It isn’t just to document; it’s to take a moment, what you see, and hold it forever.
sourceFragments: Streaming. YouTube. Instagram. Twitter. The Internet Archive.
The way we communicate is less and less bound to the present.
The moment something exists digitally, it is accessible at any time.
